My answer is every action has an equal and opposite reaction..

The bottom of the slinky resists falling momentarily due to the upper part of the slinky accelerating downward, due to the force of gravity and the the added acceleration from the stored energy in the spring tension.

The upper part of the spring is falling faster than a ball dropped simultaneously from the same height.

The energy must come from somewhere. In order to account for this added acceleration we need an equal and opposite reaction. The bottom of the slinky remains and rest, momentarily defiant to gravity.

The energy we see is the stored eleastic potential energy from the bottom half of the slinky pulling the upper half down twords the ground.

The energy spent accelerating the top slinky faster than normal accelerationdue to gravity, balances out the force of gravity pulling the bottom of the slinky.

The reason why the bottom slinky stays exactly where it is while the upper one is falling is bcz the upper slinky is being accelerated by gravity plus the spring tension.

The forces of gravity and spring tension is equally balanced on a fully stretched slinky at rest.

Therefore the equally balanced forces don't cancel out until the slinky collapses then falls to the ground.

The second experiment designed to take gravity out of the equation is wrong as the string is not stretched. If it was, releasing both ends would result in a restoring force pulling the opposite ends towards the centre. Thats the crucial part. Both ends would then accelerate towards the centre. When you add gravity to the mix the same thing happens except we now have two forces acting on each end. In the upper ends case both gravity and the restoring force ( remember the string is stretched at this point ) pull the end downwards whereas in the lower ends case the forces are equal but acting in opposite directions, gravity down,restoring up. That's what happens here.This is primarly not a wave effect as their second experiment suggests but a forces effect. For as long as the two forces acting on the lower end are equal and balanced then it will not move. The upwards restoring force is only dependent on the length of the spring as measured from the centre so until the bottom half of the spring begins to shorten that will remain constant.

Pretty interesting, it seems to defy logic.  But here's what's happening.  Normally, a horizontal slinky held stretched in two hands and released, both ends would move toward the center.  But held vertically, and where gravity is the invisible other hand stretching the slinky down, when held from the top, the bottom comes to rest at a point of equilibrium where the spring can't be stretched more due to gravity, and due to gravity the spring does not pull the bottom up any higher than this balanced length.  Now when you release the top end, remember normally both ends of a spring will usually move toward each other, unless one end is still being held, in this case by gravity.  The top comes down faster than you'd expect from free fall because you have the effect of gravity plus the effect of the spring wanting to compress working at the same time.  The bottom wants to go up, but can't because it would have to overcome gravity, and every instant of the fall the spring is becoming less stretched, and therefore the spring force is diminishing.  So even though the bottom gets lighter, the stretched portion of the spring gets shorter, and at the exact same time it is becoming easier to rise to meet the top, the spring force is decreasing, never able to lift the bottom at all.  The bottom never falls as long as it is stretched at all, because if it's stretched at all it is hanging rather than falling.  It's a matter of balancing forces, spring pulling up, gravity pulling down, a constantly changing--getting lighter--weight (the still stretched portion) and a constantly changing--getting less strong--spring force (the degree of extension between coils).  And these two forces remaining ever changing but always in balance which offset each other in such a way as to give the "hanging" portion of the slinky the appearance of being weightless.  But weightless or at a constant altitude much like an airplane would be considered weightless; balanced forces would be a better explanation than weightless.  A sheet of paper can hover in the air with the perfect air pressure underneath it that offsets the weight of the paper.

For the "Slinky Drop" all we see is falling.

There is no force pulling down, there is only falling and rising, objects seek equilibrium based on the resistance of the surrounding medium.

Examples:
submarine uses compressed air to ascend in water.

hot-air-balloon uses hot air to ascend in the air.

airplane uses pressure difference across its flying surfaces to gain lift.

Air is liquid, the mass of objects without air, weigh less.

Air-filled balloon falls slower than balloon without Air.

Helium-filled balloon rises, because it's total weight is less than the surrounding air (like oil by water).

SO, as the top half of the slinky is being pulled down by both Tension AND Gravity, the bottom half is being HELD UP by Tension and the MIDDLE is falling with gravity.

which comes from gravity. So the lower tension segments "help" the upper ones fulfill their destiny by staying put and not contributing to the COM decline. In other words, the speedy upper segments move down so fast that the lower ones have to wait or else violate the law of gravity. It balances perfectly only because it was gravity itself that set up the tension gradient in the slinky to begin with.

If the tension is removed at any point, it will begin to accelerate faster than g in proportion to how high it is, with the bottom the only section that starts falling at 9.8 m/s2. This ensures first of all that when the top is let go, it's speed will always overcome the speed any segment below it. At the same, it can't allow the COM to drop faster than 9.8 m/s2 - which happens as the top of the slinky drops. The top wants to go down faster due to highest tension, but it has this speed limit...

This is because in the inertial frame, it is not equivalent to two people letting go of both sides. Gravity, in fact, never "let go". From our reference frame, there was no change in the forces on the bottom side, only on the top side, which means the signal has to travel downward. But how fast? This is where it gets interesting. Gravity ensures that the tension in the slinky increases from bottom to top as each segment must support everything below it...

This is so interesting. Its one of those times when two principles of physics complement each other perfectly. Once let go, the entire slinky is in free fall, and thus in an inertial frame. From this frame, the bottom is being pulled toward the center of mass (COM) just as fast as the top, but from Earth's frame, the COM is falling at g = 9.8 m/s2. To keep the bottom stationary, you would think the top would travel at 2g, with the whole slinky compressing at once, but that's not what happens...

It is exactly the same thing. The slinkys tension in both experiments are at an equilibrium, such that the slinky will not move. When horizontal, the tension on the slinky isn't as great as when it is vertical, as it is not experiencing the gravitational force. The slinky has to extend before the force of tension is equal to the force of gravity. The bottom doesn't move because the spring rate of the fully extended vertical slinky is approximately equivalent and opposite to the force of gravity. @SportsMusicGamesLife Yes it would! The end only starts to fall once the wave propagating through the slinky has had time to reach the bottom (ie the top has fallen to meet the bottom). This property will be present regardless of the length.

@clementcoolguy Just think of it as each molecule of the slinky hanging from the one above it. When you let go, all molecules but the top one are still hanging from the molecule above it. First the top one drops, then the next, then the next, until the shockwave reaches the end of the slinky.

It's the same for solid object, but the shockwave travels much faster in a metal pole than a slinky.
@clementcoolguy No, the bottom of the slinky is stationary until the top falls down and reaches the base, then the entire slinky falls due to gravity.
